Award.AwardTitle: Measuring Gravity at the Micron Scale with Laser-Cooled Trapped Microspheres: a Continuation Proposal
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravity is the least understood fundamental force of nature: there is a 16 order of magnitude disparity between the energy scale of quantum gravity and that of the electromagnetic and nuclear forces. The mystery can be cast in another way: why is gravity so much weaker? As a number of recent theories have suggested, important clues related to this "hierarchy problem" can be obtained by measuring how gravity behaves at sub-millimeter distances. Such measurements could lead to exciting new discoveries of physics beyond our current knowledge. However, the gravitational force between massive objects becomes weak very rapidly as their size and separation distance changes, thus making ultra-sensitive measurements a necessity at sub-millimeter length scales. This group is developing an experiment based on new technology which could advance our understanding of gravity by several orders of magnitude at the micrometer length scale. In this approach, a test mass is suspended in a "container" made of light, leading to greatly reduced friction and enhanced sensitivity. This research program is at the forefront of current knowledge and will enhance the scientific competency of the state of Nevada, which is currently under-represented in terms of scientific endeavor. The collaboration with researchers at Stanford and the NSF-sponsored Stanford Nanofabrication facility will improve the research infrastructure for the state, opening new pathways for future collaborations involving nanotechnology. Students and postdoctoral researchers will be broadly trained in experimental physics and nanofabrication and will be well positioned for entry into the scientific workforce. The fundamental nature of this project appeals to our sense of wonder about the natural world. The nation will benefit from an improved understanding of high-energy physics related to gravitational physics at the micron-length scale, at a fraction of the cost of particle-collider experiments.

This award supports work on an experiment with the goal of using laser-cooled trapped microspheres to test for Yukawa-type deviations from Newtonian gravity at the micron length scale. By optically levitating the force sensor, an exquisite decoupling from the environment is possible, potentially yielding sub-attonewton force sensitivity. This new technique could ultimately advance our understanding of gravity at the micron length scale by a factor of 100,000 or more, probing deep into the parameter space for theoretically predicted deviations from Newtonian gravity. In addition to studies of short-range gravitational forces, the experimental technique we propose could also enable novel investigations of Casimir forces in unexplored regimes. The project is conceptually divided into three tasks: (1) calibration and optimization of the force sensitivity of the trapped cooled microspheres, (2) final assembly of the source mass and its driving mechanism, (3) investigation of systematic errors in preliminary gravity measurements. We will also investigate novel methods for cooling the levitated nanospheres, involving sympathetic cooling with cold atoms. A graduate physics course "Hybrid Quantum Systems" will be developed to complement and augment the proposed research, leading to new ideas and opportunities for advancing science, while developing students' breadth and expertise in STEM topics. This award is supported by the Gravitational Physics and the Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics programs.

Intellectual Merit:

There are four known forces in nature: electromagnetism, the strong nuclear force, the weak nuclear force, and gravity.  The fact that the strength of the gravitational force is much weaker than that of the other Standard Model forces is known as the gauge hierarchy problem: theoretically, this necessitates an extreme fine-tuning of parameters in the Standard Model of particle physics in order to explain the physically observed value of the Higgs mass. The most popular theoretical solution to this puzzle is supersymmetry, currently being searched for at the Large Hadron Collider. However, as a number of recent theories have suggested, important clues related to this ``hierarchy problem'' can be obtained in tabletop, low-energy experiments, by measuring how gravity behaves at sub-millimeter distances. Such measurements could lead to exciting new discoveries of physics beyond the Standard Model, in the form of gravitational inverse square law (ISL) violations at short-range. However, the gravitational force between massive objects becomes weak very rapidly as their size and separation distance decreases, thus making ultra-sensitive measurements a necessity at these length scales.  The best experimental constraints to date on such ISL violations at length scales between 1mm and 1um come from precision torsion balance experiments, sensitive micro-cantilever measurements, and investigations of the Casimir effect.

 In this project we have studied the viability of another type of sensor which could be useful for measurements of gravity at the micron scale, namely optically levitated dielectric microspheres. By optically levitating the force sensor, an exquisite decoupling from the environment is possible, yielding sub-aN force sensitivity at room temperature. This new technique could ultimately advance our understanding of gravity at the micron length scale by many orders of magnitude. In order to attain such sensitivity it is imperative to operate in the high vacuum regime. However the particles are initially loaded into an optical trap under low-vacuum conditions to provide damping during the loading process. Previously, we have established a set of trapping and cooling conditions which allow pumping microspheres through the intermediate vacuum region where instabilities are known to be present.  In particular we have identified these instabilities as being due to the radiometric force, and have developed a robust strategy to avoid them.

At high vacuum we have demonstrated sub-attonewton sensitivity with lifetimes exceeding days, which should be sufficient sensitivity for improved measurements of gravity at the micron scale by at least 3 orders of magnitude. We estimate that ten times further improved sensitivity can be attained with reduced laser noise at similar pressures. Our method produces trapped beads with zero or negative charge, which remains constant over the trap lifetime at high vacuum. Thus this system shows promise for precision measurements in ultrahigh vacuum requiring long averaging times, including tests of short-range gravitational forces or Casimir forces, as well as experiments on quantum optomechanics.

In this project we have demonstrated calibrated force sensing at the zeptonewton (10-21N) level using optically trapped nanoparticles in a standing wave trap. The sensitivity achieved exceeds that of any conventional room-temperature solid-state force sensor by over an order of magnitude. We are able to calibrate the force sensitivity by applying a known electric field to a charged bead with one or two excess electrons. If a particle is confined at the antinodes of an optical standing wave, by studying the motion of a particle which has been moved to an adjacent trapping site, the known spacing of the antinodes can also be used to calibrate the displacement spectrum of the particle.  This work has resulted in 4 publications in refereed journals, 1 published conference proceeding, and 21 presentations (12 invited, 9 contributed) at conferences, workshops, universities and national labs. Seven of these had the lead presenter as a student or postdoc.  We have fabricated source mass attractors for the experiment. The next step in the experiment is investigation of systematic errors in preliminary gravity measurements, with the particle trapped near a thin membrane surface acting as a shield for electromagnetic background forces.

Broader Impact:

One PhD Thesis and one Master's Thesis were supported by this award.  Six undergraduate Senior theses were supported by this award.  One postdoctoral scholar was supported by this award.  The students working on this project learned valuable techniques which make them attractive future members of the scientific workforce. Their training included optics, vacuum technology, lasers, computer-aided design and modeling, nanofabrication, electronics, data acquisition, and data analysis. The technology being developed in this project will have other impacts in the general area of precision force sensing.  In addition to tests of gravitational physics at short length scales, such technology may also be useful for gravitational wave detection, magnetic field sensing, electric field sensing, or inertial sensing. A former PhD student has begun work towards commercialization of a force sensing technique based on similar technology.
